question: Curschmann spirals are spiral-shaped mucus plugs that arise from subepithelial mucus glands in bronchi. These spirals are associated with many lung diseases. Which of the following diseases presents with these spirals?

A 17-year-old boy comes to the outpatient department with the complaint of high-grade, intermittent fever for the past 3 days. He also complains of associated rigor and chills and intense backache. Examination reveals a petechial rash over his shins. His complete blood count (CBC) reveals; hemoglobin 12.1 g/dL, total leukocyte count (TLC) 2.9 x 10^3/L, and platelets 39 x 10^3/L. What is the patient suffering from?
SIRS is a life-threatening disease that can lead to multiple organ failure, if not treated immediately. What does it stand for?

answers.option: It stands for system inflammation related syndrome
It stands for systems involved in infection syndrome
It stands for systemic inflammatory response syndrome
It stands for septicemic inflammation related syndrome
It stands for systematic infection related syndrome

question: What is the most commonly proposed mechanism for the cause of sarcoidosis?

A 20-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever, fatigue, and headache for the past 10 days. He is now experiencing agitation and hallucination, with aggressive behavior. History suggests that he suffered a dog bite 4 weeks ago. On examination, he is found to have excessive salivation, hyperreflexia, and spasticity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Which of the following is the mediator responsible for causing fever in systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)?
Which of the following is a mediator of fever in sepsis?
What is the migration of neutrophils to the site of injury from the capillaries called?
Dengue hemorrhagic fever is caused by which of the following?

answers.option: Rupturing cells releasing parasites into the bloodstream

question: What is the predominant cell in acute inflammation?
Aplastic anemia can be caused by an infectious agent. Which of the following is most likely to cause it?
What is farmer's lung?

A young patient comes to the clinic with a complaint of abdominal pain for 2 days, accompanied by a fever for the past one day. Laboratory results show increased total leukocyte count (TLC) and raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The doctor suspects the acute inflammation of the intestine. Which of the following is responsible for his symptoms and acute inflammation?

A 36-year-old woman, with a known case of HIV infection, has a very low CD4 lymphocyte count and was prescribed treatment. She is non-compliant with her medications and now presents with shortness of breath on exertion and hypoxia. Her chest X-ray reveals fine bilateral infiltrates and the computed tomography (CT) scan reports a bilateral ground-glass appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A young patient presents to the clinic with complaints of acute watery diarrhea without abdominal pain, along with vomiting. The stool is rice-watery in nature. What is the most likely cause?
Which of the following is not sexually transmitted?
Which of the following is the most common extra-salivary manifestation of mumps after puberty?
Which of the following clinical signs indicates sepsis?

answers.option: White blood cell count > 12,000 mm³ or <4000 mm³

question: A 30-year-old male has a road accident, he comes to the emergency department with severe pain and presented with several bruises on different body parts. The physician immediately starts anti-inflammatory agents as a treatment strategy. Which of the following is a hallmark of acute inflammation?

A patient comes to the emergency department with a history of prolonged cough, fever and chest infection. He is diagnosed with a case of tuberculosis after getting confirmation from the report of biopsy. Which one of the following would have been the identifying feature of tuberculosis?

A patient comes to the emergency department with fever, abdominal cramps, and a history of passing only a small amount of loose stools. Lab findings show mucous, red blood cells, and white blood cells in the stool sample. Which of the following best describes this condition?

A young male presents with painless profuse diarrhea. He is passing a large volume of stool flecked with mucus. He presents to the emergency response department dehydrated and in a state of shock. Which of the following is an appropriate statement if cholera is suspected?

answers.option: Diarrhea occurs because of vibrio cholera invasive action
Cholera toxin releases 5-hydroxytryptamine from enterochromaffin cells in the gut
Hyperchlorhydria facilitates the passage of cholera bacilli into the small intestine
It releases GABA which is responsible for its secretory effect

question: Among all the types of leprosy, which of the following has a good prognosis and may even heal itself?
Chronic granulomatous inflammation is microscopically characterized by which of the following?

answers.option: Circumscribed collection of epithelioid and multinucleated giant cells

question: Complications of measles can be very severe in certain cases. Which of the following is not considered a complication occurring several years after the episode of measles?
Which of the following is the characteristic of dengue?
Which of the following results in the primary immune defect of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)?

answers.option: Killing of CD4+ T cells due to antibody-dependent cytotoxicity
Reduction of number and effectiveness of CD4+ T cells due to killing induced by human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)

question: Which of these diseases is characterized by the presence of 'Negri bodies'?
Which of the following is a proinflammatory mediator?
What does the respiratory burst in acute inflammation help in?
How would a western blot test be deemed positive?
Which arachidonic acid metabolite is mainly responsible for leukocyte adhesion?
Which of the following is not present in granulomas?
Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) is associated with which of the following?
What is the movement of leukocytes towards an infected tissue called?

A 35-year-old diabetic patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever associated with rigor and chills and increased frequency of urine. There are no other significant findings. What is the most probable cause?

A 20-year-old female presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of fever on alternate days, documented to be 103-104 °F, along with sweating and chills. She also had malaise, vomiting, weakness, muscle pain, and headache. She was pale and had a palpable spleen on examination. What is the most likely cause?

A 7-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with a complaint of fever and vesicular rashes all over the body. The vesicles appear in bunches and some are in the healing phase. There is a history of sore throat and cough too. What is the long-term complication of the condition at a later age?

A 14-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a complaint of a hypopigmented patch on her face. On examination, it is a well-demarcated area of skin that does not respond to pain stimuli. How is the condition diagnosed?

A 6-day-old neonate is brought to the pediatric emergency with a history of fits and refusal to take feed. The fits are more severe on exposure to light and excessive sound. The neonate was delivered at home. What is the causative organism?

Shigella dysenteriae causes fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea in humans. The infection is due to the release of Shiga toxin, which promotes tissue invasion in the large intestine. What is another name for Shiga toxin?

A 25-year-old fisherman presented to the outpatient department with complaints of abdominal discomfort and diarrhea. His complete blood picture showed megaloblastic anemia and his stool had numerous oval operculated brown eggs. Which parasite is the cause of his condition?
Salmonella typhi is transmitted by the orofecal route and is the causative agent of typhoid fever. What is the primary site of infection?

answers.option: Mononuclear phagocytic cells in the large intestine
Mononuclear phagocytic cells in the liver
Mononuclear phagocytic cells in the liver and Peyer's patches
Mononuclear phagocytic cells in the spleen
Mononuclear phagocytic cells in the liver and spleen

question: A 15-year-old boy presented to the outpatient department with fever, rash, and conjunctivitis. The rash appeared first on the face and then spread to the extremities including the palms and soles. Which viral infection is the boy suffering from?

A 45-year-old man presented to the outpatient department with fever, constipation, and abdominal tenderness. Blood culture showed growth of non-lactose fermenting (colorless) gram-negative bacteria on MacConkey's agar and the production of hydrogen sulfide gas on TSI agar. What is the probable diagnosis?

A 35-year-old female presented with fever, chills, sweating, weakness, and headache, presumptively diagnosed as 'viral syndrome'. The patient's condition later deteriorated with altered level of consciousness, severe anemia, renal failure, and multisystem failure. Blood sample investigation showed malarial parasite. Crescent or sausage (banana) shaped gametocytes are a characteristic of which plasmodium species?

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) can frequently be observed in patients with severe inflammatory response and has a poor prognosis. Coagulation pathway activation leads to small vessels occlusion leading to various organ failure symptoms. Which of the following laboratory tests is used for evidence of DIC?

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) attacks the immune system and if untreated, can cause acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). HIV has several structural and non-structural proteins that play a role in infectivity. Which of the following is a structural gene of HIV?

A 23-year-old medical student develops nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea after eating street food. Her complete blood count shows hemoglobin 12.8 g/dL, white blood cells 4200/mm³, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 35 mm/h, and low platelet count (98000/μL). What is the most predominant feature of this condition?

answers.option: Disease can be transmitted by contact
Patient has petechia on the arms and legs
Can result in a chronic carrier state
Patient can present with bloody diarrhea
Patient can present with rose red spots

question: A man falls in the washroom and later presents with a high-grade fever. The doctor suspects that he has chronic inflammation. Which of the following are the dominant cells of chronic inflammation?
Which of the following cells are found in the synovium of the joint in case of acute arthritis?
Which of the following leads to the dilation of the arterioles and increased venous permeability?

A patient presents to the outpatient department with a history of cough for more than three weeks, night sweats, loss of appetite, and fever. The physician advises a chest x-ray, sputum culture, and Zeihl-nelson staining of the sputum. He was diagnosed as a case of tuberculosis. Which one of the following is an identifying feature of tuberculosis?

Malaria is an intermittent and remittent fever caused by a protozoan parasite that invades the red blood cells and is transmitted by mosquitoes in many tropical and subtropical regions. Anopheles mosquito takes a blood meal from humans and injects which of the forms of plasmodium parasite?

A 33-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with a three-day history of a white, fishy vaginal discharge. She has no history of sexually transmitted disease, post-coital bleeding, or dysuria. On speculum examination, there is a milky fluid in the posterior fornix but no signs of inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

The journey of leukocytes from the vessel lumen to the tissue is a multi-step process mediated and controlled by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines. Which one of the following statements is correct regarding sequential phases?

answers.option: Rolling, margination, and adhesion to endothelium
Adhesion, margination, and rolling to endothelium
Margination, adhesion, and rolling to endothelium
Margination in a tissue towards a chemotactic stimulus
Margination inside the endothelium and vessel wall

question: A 3-year-old unvaccinated girl is brought to the outpatient department with fever, cough, runny nose, and watery eyes for 3 days. On physical examination, there is a maculopapular rash on the face, neck, and trunk. Her elder sibling has a history of similar complaints from 1 week ago. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 6-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of high-grade fever (102°F) for 4 days. On physical examination, the child is febrile with cropped vesicles on the trunk and scattered scabbed lesions. Which of the following infections is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of purulent vaginal discharge and intermenstrual bleeding. Gram staining of endocervical screening revealed the presence of gram-negative diplococci. What would be the diagnosis?
Once the fusion of HIV takes place with the host cell, viral RNA is released into the cytoplasm. Viral RNA is then used to synthesize dsDNA by which of the following enzymes?

HIV uses a CD4⁺ molecule as a receptor, which is present in CD4⁺ cells such as T-lymphocytes, macrophages, monocytes, dendritic cells other and antigen-presenting cells. Virus entry into the human cell is mediated by which of the following proteins?

A young man presented to the emergency room with a history of high-grade fever associated with chills and rigors. He lives in an area of poor sanitation, streets with stagnant water, insects, and mosquitoes. A complete blood count (CBC) examination of blood from the patient revealed distorted RBCs, double in size, and Schüffner's dots. What is the causative agent?

A young child presented to the outpatient department with a history of low-grade fever, loss of appetite, and lethargy. Blood culture is positive for Salmonella typhi. Salmonella typhi is transmitted by which of the following routes?

A 24-year-old male patient presents with pain in his left knee and a burning sensation during urination. On examination, he has noticeable conjunctival inflammation. He denies any recent gastroenteritis but has had several sexual partners and has not always used protection. Which organism is most likely responsible for his presentation?

An eight-year-old girl was brought to ENT OPD with complaints of fever, rash, and cough. During the oral examination, the doctor noticed bright red lesions with white dots on the girl's buccal mucosa. Her mother mentioned the rash first appeared on the face and then spread to the extremities, including palms and soles. Which one of the following viruses is the most probable cause of infection?

A 5-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with complaints of water-filled blisters on his whole body including trunk and both upper and lower extremities. He also complained of severe itching along with fever ad malaise. On clinical grounds doctor suspected him to be suffering with varicella. A presumptive diagnosis of his condition can be made by which of the following techniques?
During the first week of symptoms caused by Salmonella typhi, what specimen/specimens could be collected for the routine diagnosis of enteric fever?

answers.option: PCR for bacterial isolation from serum sample
Widal test for detection of antibodies

question: A 35-year-old female patient presented with fever, chills, sweating, and headache, weakness, presumptively diagnosed as "viral syndrome." Later, the patient deteriorated with an altered level of consciousness, severe anemia, renal failure, and multisystem failure. Blood samples were sent for lab investigations including malarial parasites. Crescent or sausage (banana) shaped gametocytes are characteristic features of which of the plasmodium species?

A 6-year-old boy presents with fever, malaise, cough, running nose and conjunctivitis. The boy does not receive any childhood vaccination. On examination, his temperature is 102.7 F and there are white spots on a red base close to his second molar teeth. He also has a non-pruritic, maculopapular rash on his face, behind his ears, and spreading to his chest. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old businessman presents with flu-like symptoms, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and fever along with a weight loss of 12 kg. He acknowledges promiscuous behavior with numerous girls during his travel to different countries which raises suspicion of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). What is the name of the co-receptor required for macrophage-tropic HIV to gain entry into the host cell?

A 14-year-old girl comes to the outpatient department concerned about the white patch on her face for two years. On examination, there is a well-demarcated hypopigmented area of skin which is non-responsive to painful stimuli. What test you would prescribe to diagnose such a case?
Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) is mainly transmitted to humans through:

A 43-year-old man presented with a 3-day history of peri-umbilical pain which had localized to the right iliac fossa by the time he attended hospital. He described the pain as sharp, constant, and aggravated by movement. Examination findings revealed a soft abdomen with tenderness and guarding in the right iliac fossa. The physician suspected him of acute appendicitis. Which one of the following would be raised in acute appendicitis?

A 23-year-old lady has been complaining of right quadrant pain for the last two days. Rebound tenderness was observed on physical examination. Laparoscopic surgery was planned and swollen; reddish appendix was removed. Histopathological biopsy showed numerous infiltrations of neutrophils. Which one of the following mediators is responsible for causing pain?

A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever, malaise, and cough associated with severe pain in muscles and joints. His CBC report shows leucopenia and thrombocytopenia. The serological test report shows NS1 antigen-positive. The patient is suffering from which one of the following infectious diseases?

A 35-year-old male presented with a one-and-half-year history of pruritus, swelling, and pain involving the distal extremities and the ears. Physical examinations revealed nonpitting edema of the ears, bilateral loss of eyelashes, and ill-defined somewhat dusky, hyperpigmented patches scattered diffusely and symmetrically on his extremities with sparing of the trunk and neck. Histopathology of the skin biopsy demonstrated granulomatous infiltrates, with perineural and perivascular involvement, and a large number of acid-fast bacilli on the Ziehle Neelsen stain. What would be the diagnosis?

A 68-year-old man has had dyspnea for 3 years without any history of cough and fever. He worked in coal mines for the last 10 years. A chest x-ray shows prominent interstitial markings with nodules. Which one of the following is an identifying feature of his condition?
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by the protozoan Leishmania. During visceral leishmaniasis which organs in the human body are commonly affected?
